awd_titl_txt: Interplay of maternal transcription factors in endoderm specification
awd_abstract_narration:
Which came first: the chicken or the egg? This metaphor describes situations where it is not clear which of two events should be considered the cause and which should be considered the effect. There exists a similar question in biology during early animal development. Animal development begins when a sperm fertilizes an egg and the resulting fertilized egg creates a single cell with enormous differential potential because it is able to develop into all cell types. In frogs, within the first few hours after fertilization, a fertilized egg divides several times and develops into three cell types with distinct functions. These differentiated cells express different genes. The dilemma here is - What regulates the gene expression to give the cell identity? One idea is that DNA-binding proteins are the major drivers and these directly control gene expression. In this scenario, the expression patterns of the DNA-binding proteins are critical. Another idea is that the early embryonic DNA is very restrictive and only limited regions of DNA are accessible to DNA-binding proteins. Thus, the configuration of DNA is important. This project will address which of these two models is important. A combination of cutting edge technologies will be applied during the course of this research. In addition, this project has an outreach component, and will train undergraduates to become familiar with the latest science concepts and technology affecting biomedical sciences. 

The activation of gene transcription in the embryo relies on maternal transcription factors, which sit high in the regulatory hierarchy to coordinate the gene regulatory cascades that lead to stereotypical development of embryos. The goal of this project is to examine the earliest lineage restriction events of germ layer specification (ectoderm, mesoderm, endoderm) using Xenopus and to address how maternal transcription factors regulate embryonic genome programming. Since transcription factors drive gene expression programs by binding Cis-Regulatory Modules (CRMs) dispersed throughout the genome, a major unanswered question is how maternal transcription factors bind specific CRMs to endow the transcriptional responses. This important question can be addressed by going back to the earliest stages of embryonic development when transcription from the embryonic genome has not yet begun, the number of different cell types is small, and the genome appears relatively na?ve. Three maternal transcription factors (Otx1, VegT and Sox7) were recently identified and shown to be involved in endoderm specification. Using a combination of genomic approaches together with genetic methods, both gain- and loss-of-function mutants of these maternal transcription factors will be analyzed to determine the mechanisms by which individual CRM activities are coordinately activated, and ensure subsequent epigenetic modifications of the genome.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our research focuses on understanding the complex process of gene regulation during early animal development, especially during the early embryonic gut formation. The gut is a crucial organ that plays a central role in digestion and nutrient absorption, and understanding how it develops is important for our understanding of overall animal development and health.  

One key aspect of gene regulation is the precise timing and location of gene expression, which is tightly controlled during animal development. This process needs to be repeated accurately in every cell and every generation to endure the proper formation and function of the organism. The orchestration of gene expression is regulated by special proteins called transcription factors, which bind to specific regions of the DNA and control the activation or repression of genes. In our research, we use highly sophisticated computational approaches to analyze gene expression profiling data, which provides us with valuable insights into the activity of key transcription factors that regulate early embryogenesis. These methods also allow us to study the patterns of gene expression during different stages of development and identify the specific transcription factors that are involved in the regulation of the early gut development. 

To dissect the role of transcription factors during early gut development, we conducted experiments using frog embryos as a model organism. Frog embryos are ideal for studying early development because they share many similarities with human embryos, but are more accessible for experimental manipulation. We manipulate the frog embryos to study the effects of removing or altering the expression levels of specific transcriptional factors during gut development. 

Through our experiments, we have identified three critical transcriptional factors, Sox7, VegT, and Otx2, which are localized within the egg and have been implicated in the early gut development. We hypothesized that these transcription factors expressed in eggs play a central role in activating the embryonic genome and initiating the gut gene regulatory program. Our experiments have shown that in the absence of these transcription factors, embryonic gut development is severely disrupted, highlighting their essential role in gut formation.  Furthermore, our research has provided insights into how these transcription factors work together to regulate gene expression. We have found that the cooperative activity of all three transcription factors is required for proper gut development, emphasizing the importance of their interplay in controlling gene expression during early development. Lastly, we have also discovered that these transcription factors bind to specific regions of the embryonic DNA before recruiting enzymes that are essential for initiating the activation of the early gut-related genes. 

Overall, our study has established the first comprehensive gene interaction network that controls the earliest stages of cell state commitment in vertebrates, using amphibians as an experimental model. This “bird’s eye view” of gene regulation in gut development provides important insights that may help uncover the mechanisms underlying early human embryonic gut development. Further research in this area may have applications in regenerative medicine and the development of therapeutic interventions for gut-related disorders.
